title: 104_s974
content: The Act may be cited as the "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" and prohibits certain activities. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" amends definitions in the United States Code related to wire and computer fraud, and prohibits the use of computers in furtherance of racketeering activities. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" expands criminal penalties and civil remedies related to electronically or digitally stored data in the United States Code. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" expands penalties and remedies for data-related crimes in the United States Code, including authorization for interception of communications and procedures for interception. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" expands penalties for computer crimes in the United States Code, including prohibiting the transfer of unlicensed software and distributing encryption software to foreign entities. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" prohibits the distribution of unlicensed software and the use of a computer network to conceal the origin of assets derived from racketeering activity. It also prohibits operating a computer network to facilitate racketeering activity or engage in illegal conduct. Each act of distributing software is considered a separate offense, and accessing nonexportable software by foreign entities is also a separate offense. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" prohibits unlicensed software distribution. An affirmative defense is allowed if the software used a universal decoding device provided to the Department of Justice. The "Anti-Electronic Racketeering Act of 1995" prohibits unlicensed software distribution and includes jurisdiction and venue provisions for crimes involving computers within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States. The jurisdiction and venue for computer-related crimes are determined by the physical location of the computer, computer facility, or computer network at the time of the offense. Amendments are made to various sections of the law to include computer networks and facilities in wire and computer fraud, as well as in the Privacy Protection Act of 1980 to allow for immediate seizure of materials to prevent destruction. Amendments are made to various sections of the law to include computer networks and facilities in wire and computer fraud, as well as in the Privacy Protection Act of 1980 to allow for immediate seizure of materials to prevent destruction, including electronically stored data. The seizure must be incidental to a valid seizure, and steps must be taken to protect privacy interests upon discovery of work product materials. The section recognizes interests in using utility software to identify electronically stored data and protect privacy by seeking a search warrant upon identification of such material.
